newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Metro Pacific agrees to raise Smart stake.
newsitem.headline: Metro Pacific agrees to raise Smart stake.

text.p: Diversified concern Metro Pacific Corp (MPC) said on Thursday its board agreed to raise its stake in affiliate Smart Communications Inc to strike a balance between its real estate and telecommunication portfolios.

"The higher level of ownership in Smart will raise significantly MPC's investment in telecommunications; thereby providing a better balance in MPC's investment portfolio in terms of risks, recurring income and cash flow, and growth prospects," a Metro Pacific statement said.
Metro Pacific is the lead developer of the 214-hectare Bonifacio property being built at the edge of the financial district of Makati.

"The agreement to increase MPC's investment in Smart will represent a significant transaction, and is a key development for the MPC Group in terms of its planned strategy of diversification," president Napoleon Nazareno said.
Metro Pacific director Seumas Gallacher said the company would issue new shares in exchange for Smart shares held by Metro Pacific's parent First Pacific Co Ltd.
"No cash will change hands," Gallacher told Reuters.
First Pacific said Metro Pacific would have a majority economic interest in Smart following the deal, up from 28 percent at present.
The other major investor of Smart, the Phillippines' largest celular phone provider, is Japan's Nippon Telegraph and Telephone Corp (NTT).
The share swap is expected to be finalised before Smart's initial public offering (IPO) which is tentatively scheduled in the third quarter of the year.
After the swap, Hong-Kong based First Pacific's stake in Smart will be significatly reduced to allow more foreign fund managers to participate in the IPO.
A Philippine law allows foreigners to own up to 40 percent of a telecom company.
NTT was assured its 15 percent stake would not be diluted in the process.
First Pacific said its holding in Metro Pacific would be determined based on the share prices of Smart and Metro at the time of the IPO.
Aside from property and telecom, Metro Pacific is also involved in consumer products, packaging and banking.
